data.title: Request for tabbing past matching brackets similar to VS

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

I would like to request a feature to allow tabbing past matching brackets (parens, braces, etc.) instead of being required to type the exact matching bracket or use a right arrow key, similar to the behavior in recent versions of Visual Studio. Reason: makes typing much faster and more accurate and is more comfortable than using arrow keys

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Begin typing an expression with a left bracket, e.g. `[`
2. The right bracket appears by default, e.g. `[|]` where `|` is the cursor
3. Finish typing the expression, e.g. `[int|]`
4. What I would like: press Tab, cursor moves past the right bracket: `[int]|`
5. What actually happens: a tab character or some number of spaces are inserted:` [int    |]`

data.title: "files.autoSave": "onFocusChange"
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04

Problem:
`"files.autoSave": "onFocusChange"` not working correctly. I write something in file, I switch to another file, but it will not be auto-saved. For e.g. I change code in `server.js`, I switch to `client.js` it will not be saved. As I read here https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/353, @bpasero said:

> you switch to another file or close the file
> you quit the app
> you move to another app so that code looses focus

P.S. It only works if I change to Untitled document which is created, but not saved and only for the first time.

I don't know if it's problem, but I will be really in love with such function.

data.title: Feature/part resize: Add key bindings to resize focused view
data.body:
See issue #22645 


Part Resize Feature Notes:


Proposed feature to address issue #22645:
	Keyboard bindings to expand or contract the main axis of the focused view

Two key bindings expand view, contract view

key bindings based on part focus (potential reduction of key collisions)

expansion or contraction follow main axis of part and orientation

eg sidebar has focus, expand moves border right if on left
or left if sidebar on right
eg panel has focus expand moves border up...
editor focus: expand moves right border right (h. layout)
top up (v. layout) or opposite if single editor
approach still works if a new part eg secondary sidebar
is added in the future

Possible (mnemonic) key bindings: (probably none assigned by default)

[expand part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ >
[contract part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ <

[expand part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ x
[contract part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ c

[expand part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ )
[contract part]: ctrl+alt+shift+ (

[restore default part size]: ctrl+alt+shift+ d
[restore default part size]: ctrl+alt+shift+ r

Potential Future Issues:

A part with no "primary axis" (expanding contract ambiguous)

Main file work:

Main file, follows toggleSideBarVisibility.ts design approach
- workbench command registrations
- action functions

.\src\vs\workbench\browser\actions\resizePart.ts

Workbench Support Functions
- set up per Part
- access to workbench layout
.\src\vs\workbench\electron-browser\workbench.ts

Layout Support Functions
- adjust main access dimensions pre- layout call
- possible reset to default option
.\src\vs\workbench\browser\layout.ts

The prototype implementation sports resize
of the sidebar, the panel and one editor.

After looking more into the code base as well
as the navigation contribution by @misoguy
I think some files need to be moved around.
my first implementation was based on toggleSideBarVisibility
but I think the more recent code  add
the commands to actions.ts

The next step is to flush out support for the editors
where more than one is visible. and re- factor
per suggestion input.

Thanks for considering...

data.title: Add multi-select to Quick Pick extension API
data.body: It would be nice there was a QuickPickOption that enables the user to select multiple items by, for example, holding shift while navigating the item list or control-clicking items. This would be very useful for extensions which can generate getters/setters among others.

data.title: Allow Moving between File Explorer and Open Editors with Keyboard
data.body:
Keybindings for navigation in lists/trees were introduced recently.

While this is a big help in achieving good vim keybindings, it immediately breaks down in the explorer.

The explorer is almost like a tree with two top level items, `Open Files` and `File Explorer`, but you can not navigate between them or expand/collapse them with the intuitive keys (up/down, left/right).

While most users use the mouse anyway, this is quite crucial for having good vim keybindings, since I really hate switching to the mouse for something like this.

I have no clue about the internal structure, but could the Explorer be made to implement a List and enable the new `list.*` commands?

data.title: -clicking on path:line:col in iTerm2 opens a new window and ignores :line:col.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3 (16D32)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Generate some compiler output in iTerm that includes _path:line:col_ entries, e.g. `foo/bar/file.go:123:25`.
2. Ensure the file is opened in a VSCode tab. For good measure, have another tab in focus.
3. -click on the file in iTerm2.
  - The file opens in a new VSCode window with the cursor positioned at the start of the file.
4. Close the new VSCode window.
5. Run `code -g foo/bar/file.go:123`.
  - The existing VSCode tab moves comes into focus with the specified line centered, and the cursor is positioned at the specified line and column. In short, behavior is as expected.
6. Repeating steps 15 with just _path:line_ (no _:col_) exhibits the same anomalous behavior.

I switched away from Sublime Text 3 yesterday, and it was behaving as expected, so I suspect it's a problem with how VSCode specifies file opening behavior, not with iTerm2, _per se_.

data.title: Transform :emojis: to real emojis in commit messages
data.body:
Hello!

Emojis in commit messages are being counted towards the maximum recommended character length. Since the emoji isn't being transformed in VS Code, its obviously just seeing the `:eggplant:` key as normal characters.

Example: (this message is 51 characters if you include `:eggplant:`)
![Image](http://i.imgur.com/AJJmHar.png)

It could be argued that this is intentional, as the emoji keys aren't transformed to actual emoji characters as a part of VS Code's Git integration; it's usually done by GitHub, Bitbucket, etc.

If that's the case then maybe VS Code should transform emojis in commit messages to actual emojis before being logged into Git, so that (for example) `git log` would show the emojis in terminal, and then change the recommended character length to treat `:*:` as one character.

[Emoji Cheat Sheet](https://www.webpagefx.com/tools/emoji-cheat-sheet/) (or something else) could be used to determine if a `:*:` fragment is in fact an emoji.

Would love to hear some thoughts on this.
Thanks!
